## Finding Data

* [Jenn Huck](https://data.library.virginia.edu/jennifer-huck/), UVA's Data Librarian and [the library's Data Resources pages](https://data.library.virginia.edu/datasources/)
* [Find and Question Your Data](https://handsondataviz.org/find.html), from Jack Dougherty and Ilya Ilyankou, Hands-On Data Visualization.
* [Data.gov](https://www.data.gov/), home of the U.S. Government’s open data
* [CDC Wonder](https://wonder.cdc.gov/), public health-related data
* [FBI Crime data explorer](https://crime-data-explorer.app.cloud.gov/pages/home), for criminal, noncriminal, law enforcement data 
* [Small Business Adminsitration's PPP data](https://www.sba.gov/funding-programs/loans/covid-19-relief-options/paycheck-protection-program/ppp-data)
* [World Bank](https://data.worldbank.org/), open access to global development data
* [US City Open Data Census](http://us-cities.survey.okfn.org/), the Sunlight Foundation and Code for America collects data on city open data portals throughout the U.S.
* [Charlottesville Open Data Portal](https://opendata.charlottesville.org/)
* [Data is Plural](https://www.data-is-plural.com/), Jeremy Singer-Vine's weekly newsletter of useful/curious datasets
* [Erik Gahner’s list of political science datasets](https://github.com/erikgahner/PolData), a huge list of useful datasets, divided by topic (governance, elections, policy, political elites, etc.).
* [Urban Institute's Data Catalog](https://datacatalog.urban.org/search/type/dataset)
* [Google Dataset Search](https://datasetsearch.research.google.com/), search for thousands of public data sets indexed by Google.
* [Kaggle Datasets](https://www.kaggle.com/datasets), datasets hosted for various data science competitions over the years
* So many sources... <div style="text-align:right;"><img src="https://media.giphy.com/media/xT9C25UNTwfZuk85WP/giphy.gif" width="200" style="display: inline-block; margin: 0"></div>

## Visualization Inspiration

* [The Pudding](https://pudding.cool/)
* [BBC Visual and Data Journalism cookbook for R graphics](https://bbc.github.io/rcookbook/)
* [Fivethirtyeight examples](https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-40-weirdest-and-best-charts-we-made-in-2020/) and their [data archive](https://data.fivethirtyeight.com/)
* [Visualizing Data](https://www.visualisingdata.com/), by Andy Kirk (check out the archive of [monthly/weekly best of lists](https://www.visualisingdata.com/2021/06/best-of-the-visualisation-web-april-2021/))
* [Flowing Data](https://flowingdata.com/), by Nathan Yau
* [Information is Beautiful](https://informationisbeautiful.net/), by David McCandless
* [Data Viz Weekly](https://www.anychart.com/blog/category/data-visualization-weekly/), weekly examples by AnyChart
* [Seeing Data](http://seeingdata.org/), by a collection of researchers
* [Info we Trust](https://infowetrust.com/essays), by RJ Andrews
* [UW Interactive Data Lab](https://idl.cs.washington.edu/), a computer science lab at University of Washington to enhance the understanding and communication of data 
* [Visual Thinking Lab](https://visualthinking.psych.northwestern.edu/projects.html), a psychology lab at Northwestern studying visual thinking
* [PolicyViz](https://policyviz.com/), by Jonathan Schwabisch

## Data Art

* [Hand Crafted](https://www.williamrchase.com/work/), by William R. Chase
* [Data Paintings](http://giorasimchoni.com/2017/07/30/2017-07-30-data-paintings-the-kandinsky-package), by Giora Simchoni
* [Data to Art](https://www.data-to-art.com/), curated by Yan Holtz
* [Dear Data](https://www.dear-data.com/theproject), by Giorgia Lupi and Stefanie Posavec
* [Martin Wattenberg](http://www.bewitched.com/art.html) and [Fernanda Viegas](http://www.fernandaviegas.com/) collaborations (science and art)
* [Amplifying Data through Art](https://www.hakaimagazine.com/article-short/amplifying-data-through-art/), profile of artists who represent data
* [Accidental aRt](https://twitter.com/accidental__aRt), twitter account of data viz errors that might be art
* [Data Visualization and the Modern Imagination](https://exhibits.stanford.edu/dataviz), an exhibit at Stanford Libraries

## Mapping

* [tiydcensus](https://walker-data.com/tidycensus/index.html) for pulling census data, and mapping with [ggplot::geom_sf](https://walker-data.com/tidycensus/articles/spatial-data.html)
* More ggplot::geom_sf[examples](https://r-spatial.org/r/2018/10/25/ggplot2-sf.html) and [tutorials](https://evamaerey.github.io/flipbooks/geom_sf/geom_sf.html#1)
* Examples with [ggplot::geom_polygon and ggmaps](http://eriqande.github.io/rep-res-web/lectures/making-maps-with-R.html)
* Using [tmap](https://geocompr.robinlovelace.net/adv-map.html) and a great resource for using spatial data in R more generally
* [Leaflet example](https://www.earthdatascience.org/courses/earth-analytics/get-data-using-apis/leaflet-r/)
